item.title: George Floyd: Chauvin conviction a giant step forward, says Biden
item.description: The US president welcomes the conviction in the George Floyd murder case but says more must be done.

item.title: All six English clubs leave European Super League
item.description: All six Premier League teams involved in the European Super League formally withdraw from the competition.

item.title: Boris Johnson told Sir James Dyson by text he would 'fix' tax issue
item.description: The prime minister and businessman sent text messages over plans for ventilators during the pandemic.

item.title: Ella Adoo-Kissi-Debrah: Coroner calls for air pollution law change after girl's death
item.description: An inquest finds air pollution "made a material contribution" to Ella Adoo-Kissi-Debrah's death.

item.title: Ohio shooting: Columbus police shoot dead black teenage girl
item.description: The shooting in Columbus happened as police were responding to an attempted stabbing call.

item.title: Daily Mail owner sues Google over search results
item.description: The owner of the MailOnline site alleges the search engine has hidden links to its coverage on certain topics.

item.title: Rising fuel costs drive UK inflation to 0.7% in March
item.description: The cost of living rose to 0.7% in March, from 0.4% in February, as fuel, transport and clothes prices increased.

item.title: Netflix shares plunge amid fears coronavirus boom is over
item.description: Netflix said the pandemic disrupted its production pipeline and has forecast fewer new subscribers.

item.title: Queen will mark 95th birthday in low-key fashion
item.description: The monarch's birthday on Wednesday comes four days after the funeral of her husband, Prince Philip.

item.title: Climate change: Growing doubts over chip fat biofuel
item.description: A new study questions the sustainability of used cooking oil imports into Europe to make biodiesel.

item.title: Mother gives birth in dramatic Uber hospital dash
item.description: Victoria White's waters broke as she was being driven to hospital to give birth to her second child.

item.title: The Papers: Super League 'in tatters' and Chauvin found guilty
item.description: Wednesday's front pages continue to chart the fate of football's "crumbling" European Super League.

item.title: George Floyd: Family reacts to Derek Chauvin murder conviction
item.description: George Floyd's family react to the murder conviction of Derek Chauvin who knelt on Floyd's neck.

item.title: The beauty ideal fuelling an illicit drugs trade
item.description: For Altou, a 19-year-old model, having a ‘slim thick’ body is the key to getting more likes and more work.

item.title: London elections: 'I don't feel welcome in this city'
item.description: Accessible transport campaigner Katie Pennick says a lack of progress by consecutive London mayors has left her feeling "unwelcome".

item.title: Surfer reunited with big wave board discovered 2,700km away
item.description: Danny Griffiths was stunned when a surfboard he had lost four years earlier turned up 2,700km away.

item.title: Shanghai Auto Show: Five electric car brands to look out for in China
item.description: Robin Brant talks through five companies showcasing electric vehicles at the Shanghai Auto Show.

item.title: CEO Secrets: 'No money is better than the wrong money'
item.description: CEO Augustin Celier says he was tempted by a €500,000 loan "but it could have ruined our company".

item.title: Deer graze on east London housing estate
item.description: Surprised residents wake up to find a herd of deer grazing on their doorstep.

item.title: 'My sister took her life, petrified at facing her ex in court'
item.description: Gemma Robinson died just days before she was due to see her ex-partner in court.

item.title: Covid-19 in India: Why second coronavirus wave is devastating
item.description: A deadly second wave has overrun hospitals and even crematoriums in India.

item.title: Oscars 2021: The lowdown on the international feature nominees
item.description: The five films cover diverse topics from bullying, a drinking experiment, and the horror of war.

item.title: Coronapas: The passport helping Denmark open up after Covid
item.description: Football fans, museums and restaurants are opening up, but Danes will have to show a corona passport.

item.title: Navalny's supporters fear Russia's Putin wants him dead
item.description: President Putin's leading critic is on hunger strike and ahead of planned street protests they warn he could die.

item.title: George Floyd death: Five key moments from the Derek Chauvin trial
item.description: Here are key elements of a trial that gripped the US.

item.title: Derek Chauvin conviction: 'This is monumental. This is historic'
item.description: The conviction of the police officer for the death of George Floyd has been hailed as a watershed.

item.title: Oscars 2021: 19 geeky facts from Borat to Boseman
item.description: Everything you need to know ahead of the 93rd Academy Awards on Sunday.

item.title: Could electric tattoos be the next step in body art?
item.description: Researchers are experimenting with thin, flexible circuits that can be transferred to the skin.

item.title: 'I let you down' - Liverpool owner apologises to fans for ESL involvement
item.description: Liverpool owner John W Henry apologises to Reds supporters for the club's involvement in a proposed European Super League.

item.title: European Super League timeline: Game changer - football's volatile 48 hours
item.description: Just when you thought this season could not get any stranger, along came a plan that appeared to divide the game and then united fans in fighting against it.

item.title: Ed Woodward: Manchester United executive vice-chairman to stand down at end of 2021
item.description: Manchester United executive vice-chairman Ed Woodward will step down from his role at the end of 2021.

item.title: Chelsea go fourth in draw with Brighton on dramatic night for European football
item.description: Chelsea draw with Brighton to climb into the Champions League places on a dramatic night for the future of European football.

item.title: Fight Talk: Anthony Joshua, Tyson Fury, Jake Paul, Andy Ruiz Jr, Dave Allen
item.description: Does Anthony Joshua have a date clash going into his Tyson Fury bout? And what next for Jake Paul?

item.title: WSL top two to face off in potential title decider
item.description: Manchester City boss Gareth Taylor says the Women's Super League clash against Chelsea is one of those "moments we should cherish".

item.title: Is the Australia-NZ travel bubble the way ahead?
item.description: Australia and New Zealand have quarantine-free travel, but will other countries follow their lead?

item.title: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: Pubs and gyms will reopen in Scotland on Monday, as lockdown restrictions ease significantly.

item.title: Covid: When can I go on holiday abroad or in the UK?
item.description: A traffic light system ranking foreign countries by coronavirus risk is to be introduced - the rules on UK holidays are also easing.

item.title: Covid: Restaurants and pubs have reopened, but what are the rules?
item.description: Pubs, cafes and restaurants in England are open for customers seated outdoors.

item.title: Covid: How do I get a lateral flow or PCR test?
item.description: Everyone in England and Scotland is being encouraged to take rapid coronavirus tests regularly.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: What are the Indian, Brazil, South Africa and UK variants?
item.description: Cases are being found in the UK and the changes the virus is undergoing are concerning.

item.title: When does the stamp duty holiday in England and Northern Ireland end?
item.description: What is the stamp duty holiday and when will it finish?

item.title: Which countries are on the red list and what are the quarantine rules?
item.description: Many travellers are no longer allowed to enter the UK from countries on the "red list".

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: People 45 or over in England are being offered a Covid vaccine.

item.title: Coronavirus: What's the risk on transport?
item.description: As UK coronavirus restrictions continue to be relaxed, public transport could become much busier.

item.title: Covid: When will children return to school and what are the rules?
item.description: Children are returning to school across the UK, after months of enforced home-schooling.

item.title: Why are so many babies dying of Covid-19 in Brazil?
item.description: As the pandemic rages in Brazil, hundreds of babies and young children are dying of Covid.

item.title: The disabled doctors not believed by their colleagues
item.description: People often feel nervous when they visit a doctor, but what if you are a doctor but your colleagues don't believe you're ill?

item.title: The homeless drug addict who became a professor
item.description: Jesse Thistle, a high school dropout, overcame addiction and homelessness to pursue an academic career.

item.title: Nil-by-mouth foodie: The chef who will never eat again
item.description: Loretta Harmes hasn't eaten or tasted food for six years, but she hasn't lost her passion for cooking.

item.title: Prince Philip: A turbulent childhood stalked by exile, mental illness and death
item.description: In marrying, Philip was able to regain the "simple pleasures" of family life he had lost aged eight.
